head.title: To Save One Twin, or Lose Both

hedline.hl1: To Save One Twin, or Lose Both

abstract.p: Dr John Respass letter on Rev Robert A Sirico's Sept 28 article holds doctors are right to try to save one conjoined twin rather than let both die

block.p: Re ''An Unjust Sacrifice,'' by Robert A. Sirico (Op-Ed, Sept. 28):

Father Sirico's argument reduces to the assertion that we should not kill, a laudable intention. But treating the case of the conjoined twins in England this simplistically merely results in two deaths as opposed to one. Instead, the moral decision is to save one of the children.
Re ''An Unjust Sacrifice,'' by Robert A. Sirico (Op-Ed, Sept. 28):

Father Sirico's argument reduces to the assertion that we should not kill, a laudable intention. But treating the case of the conjoined twins in England this simplistically merely results in two deaths as opposed to one. Instead, the moral decision is to save one of the children.

Detaching the underdeveloped infant from her twin is no different from withdrawing artificial life support from a terminally ill patient who cannot otherwise survive (an action endorsed by most Catholic and Jewish ethicists). Refusal to act is an abdication of responsibility.
JOHN RESPASS, M.D. Hamden, Conn., Sept. 28, 2000
